body: WIll merge this once Travis finishes.

Even with all the fields filled, it was not starting: http://i.imgur.com/5WXKw9N.png

the log file also contained no helpful information

Hi @rmetzger. Thanks for testing. 
Error reporting could be improved. I'm working on more detailed stack traces right now.

As for the failing program, is it possible to share the Jar file? I'm parsing similar arguments and they're passed successfully to the program in fact.

here is the jar file: https://transfer.sh/KNAnm/flink0.10-scala2.11-1.0-snapshot.jar

it has been build from here: https://github.com/rmetzger/scratch/tree/flink0.10-scala2.11/

Hi @gallenvara, I read your PR and have some comments.

First, since Flink 0.10, we dropped Java 6 support and can use omit types if the types can be inferred. So could you remove type description in that case? With removing, we can make codes more readable.

Second, to convert Scala sequence to Java list, using `JavaConverters` is better than `JavaConversions`. For example:

``` scala
import scala.collection.JavaConverters._

~skipped~

val result = ds.collect()
val expected = "~~~"

TestBaseUtils.compareResultAsText(result.asJava, expected)
```

After importing `scala.collection.JavaConverters._`, we can convert Scala collection to Java collection with `asJava` method.
Thank you! I fixed this before I saw your pull request. Could you close the pr?
Hi @rmetzger , are you sure you built the source with scala 2.11? I was getting the same error you showed here, but building with scala 2.11 fixes it.

Yeah. :D
I should've waited. You were already transitioning everything for 0.10.

the jar has been build with scala 2.11 yes, flink with scala 2.10.
But I still expect a good exception in the web frontend for this.

Yes. I will write some better exception reporting. As for this particular error, how can it be detected? 
From what I observed, ideally, `Client#getOptimizedPlan` sets `OptimizerPlanEnvironment` which in turn constructs an `StreamPlanEnvironment`. But when the scala version doesn't match, the `execute` call delegates to the default `ExecutionEnvironment#execute` instead of `StreamPlanEnvironment#execute`, which of course leads to error since yours was a Streaming program.  Can't quite see why that should happen.
Maybe it makes sense to just show the entire exception to the user, instead of trying to cut away parts of the stack trace?

Yes. Except for the trace leading up to the handler, I think rest should be okay to show. In case the exception isn't`ProgramInvocationException` or `CompilerException`, something went really wrong anyway, in which case there's no harm printing the entire stack trace.
Fixing it right now.
Okay, let me know when you are ready for another test drive

Okay. So I didn't actually cut down on the stack trace. Just made sure that if it's an `ProgramInvocationException` and has an underlying cause, the cause is printed on top, so all the useless trace from netty and web monitor is at the bottom. Otherwise, everything is printed.
@rmetzger

Okay, I'll test it again.
This time, I'm building Flink with Scala 2.11.

Good news. Test on cluster was successful.
I'll take another look at the code, but otherwise +1 from my side.
Oh yay. Cool! :)

I have updated the description, and ran some more cluster tests without any issues.

It would be good if you all could do a second round of reviews please.

Thanks for the interest in helping us maintain clear code.

I think actually that the original code was easier than the code with counter checks. Further more, it moves branches away from loops (easier optimizable by the JIT compiler). Finally, the new code will be wrong if the counter overflows/wraps around, which is not unthinkable. 4 Billion elements is quite within the scope of many applications.

I am curious about other opinions.

@StephanEwen , thank you for your feedback. Looping with an int variable is clearly wrong in Flink's use case, and I can change to long, but, I'd like to hear more of this refactor. I'd withdraw this PR if it is not what the community prefer at the first place. Let me know!

I'm not too fond of the new version either and feel like this code bit doesn't really need more clarity, simply because it isn't a lot of code. 

Using a counter at all doesn't really make sense to me, you aren't counting anything effectively. a Boolean seems more intuitive. It is nit-picky but we are going for clarity here after all :)

Hi, @chiwanpark . Thanks for your review. I'm not very clear about your first suggestion. Do you mean that we should remove type description when to create a new generics? 
For example: 
`DataSource<Tuple2<Float, String>> input = env.fromElements(new Tuple2<Float, String>(1f, "Hello"))`
-->
`DataSource<Tuple2<Float, String>> input = env.fromElements(new Tuple2<>(1f, "Hello"))`
@gallenvara Yes, exactly right.
Thank you for your input. @zentol ! Withdrawing PR.
FYI: I let my test run over the weekend (i.e. for 65 hours) with the 5 & 10 minutes ticket times and it is still running fine.
I'm looking at it again.
Thanks for testing this so thoroughly. +1 to merge.
Merging this.
I am excited to see this in as well :)

@gyfora this is the PR I was talking about regarding your _connection reset_ exception. If you want, you can add the `PipelineErrorHandler` at the end of current pipeline and rerun your program to check the origin of that exception.
I will probably do this for future runs. :+1:
Yes, that's correct. Nice diagram :) Could you post it to the mailing list when you're finished? Thank you!

Thanks for the PR =)

There seems like some extra changes which not related to changing the package declaration which related to code clean up. We prefer to have code cleanup done as separate PR or commit.
Could you either:
1. Update the PR subject and description by adding more comments in both commit and PR to add information about what changes included. This definitely more that what FLINK-3013 cover.
2. Revert the changes non related to changing the package declaration?

Thanks again for the contribution.

LGTM 
+1
@mxm for sure will send to the community once it is done.
Updated the PR title and description
Hi, @chiwanpark . I have modified the code and submitted a new commit. Can you help me with review work?
Okay I'll review soon. Thanks for update.
Any way to test for this fix?
@tillrohrmann this is the nitpick PR we talked about
+1 Like previously discussed this seems to be a good strategy.

That looks much cleaner!

+1 to merge
Thanks for the fix, I just merged it.
Looks good, will merge this...
Useful addition, +1 from my side
Will merge this...

Looks correct (and affects only logging).

Will merge this...

How about using a try-with-resources statement here?
I would like to use this whenever we touch code that needs to ensure closing a resource...

Looks good, merging this!

BTW: It also affects the docs of the 0.10 release, so I will cherry pick it into the 0.10.x branch as well.
Trying this out...
Tests pass, will merge this...
Will merge this for 1.0 and 0.10.0 ...

Two questions:
1. The `chill-avro` dependency is added nowhere. Is it not necessary any more?
2. It is necessary to add the chill dependency also to `flink-clients`? Is that not covered by `flink-scala`. Asked differently, is there a need for Chill to be in the classpath of user code programs that do not use the Scala API?
Will merge and address the comments...

1. No, it seemed that `chill-avro` was not used.
2. Chill is required when Java programs are submitted to a cluster that include collection data sets. The cluster will have chill in the classpath and therefore use differently initialized Kryo serializers to read the collection data than the client without chill. I know this is a bit hacky, but the best solution I came up with.

@fhueske I've addressed most of your concerns.

Things that still need work / clarification:
- PreviewPlanDumpTest was previously executed with 2 different sets of arguments, now only with 1. Should this be changed back to the previous behaviour? The arguments affect paths for sources/sink, parallelism and the number of Iterations
- test.classloading.jar.KMeansForTest appears to be a good replacement for the IterativeKMeansITCase, what's your take on that?
- The removed delta ilteration PageRank program looks very similar to the ConnectedComponents implementation under flink-examples. I don't think this needs a separate port.

Why to we need chill for collection data sets?

Also, are you sure chill-avro was never used? No magic reflection loading happening anywhere?

I verified the intended behaviour on a cluster application, it works for cancelling from both the command line and also from the web interface.

+1 from my side, this is a critical fix for production environments
I can confirm that `chill-avro` was never used. I accidentally committed the dependency while trying out different approaches for handling Avro POJOs with Flink.
+1 to merge. I tried this with a testing job and its working now
I thought generic types within collections data sets are serialized with Kryo when they are shipped to the JM, no? Or are they going through Java serialization?
Thanks a lot for the PR @smarthi! +1 to merge.
Generic types go through Kryo, but kryo works without Chill. Chill only adds Scala Serializers, or does it also add Java and Util Serializers?

What if a user registers a custom type in Kryo on the client side? That type would receive a different ID, because fewer types have been registered at the client compared to the Chill initialized Kryo instance at the server. Or am I missing something here?

several travis builds failed:
oraclejdk8 & hadoop 2.7: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-2771
oraclejdk8 & hadoop 2.5: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-2392
openjdk7 & hadoop 2.4: error in test: JobManagerSubmittedJobGraphsRecoveryITCase.cleanUp:111  ConnectionLoss Keeper...

I think all of those are not related to the javadoc change. :)

Other than small nit on text, +1

Seems like Travis fails unrelated to this patch
+1 to merge

I just rebased this. Due to the new JobManager WebUI, I added a second commit to add STOP button to WebUI (which this does not work yet). I will squash both commits later on. I just pushed this rebase, such that the actual changes which are independent from the WebUI can get reviewed already.

I think this can be a problem. The client and server side should use a Kryo serializer which is initialized (wrt the registered types) identically. Otherwise the mapping is incorrect and the deserialization will most likely fail.

The screenshots look very nice, this will be a good feature!

A few things in the internals could be cleaned up:
- Mixing of path and query params into one map
- Putting endpoint address into the map
- Error handling seems to always give a "Bad Request" error code. Would be good to react to that properly, return a "Not Fount" or "Already Exists", or whatever, specific to the situation. This may require to create an Exception class (RequestException) that contains the response message and desired return code.

Makes sense. So in the end, we need to make sure that all actual runtime related close uses the same serializers.

Should we add one single chill dependency to `flink-runtime` then?

That means `flink-scala` would not have one, which would be okay, it needs not have one if it is only used to write against, never to execute.
Sounds good to me

Thanks a lot for fixing this @tillrohrmann!
I actually like the new behavior better ;) Could you please also update the gelly guide?
One more thing, some of the formatting changes you've made are also present in #1356. I was planning to merge it, but you'll have to rebase this one. Let me know if that's OK or whether it's more convenient for you to merge #1356 and this one yourself. Thanks again!
This has been merged, @StephanEwen probably forgot to close the PR, so I'm closing it manually.

I am confused why the build failed... It worked locally **and** on my personal travis: https://travis-ci.org/mjsax/flink/builds/91638981

Furthermore, if I understand the error message correctly, it complains that `MyErroneousTimestampSource` does not implement method `stop()` -- however, the code shows clearly that the method got added... (line 587, 588).
I think RabbitMQ is written in Erlang and does not run in the JVM. We could provide a test that expects a running RabbitMQ server somewhere (locally).
Since Flink 0.10.1 is around the corner, we should merge this PR ;)

Travis is caching the contents of the .m2 directory. Maybe that caused some weird issues.

I also had some travis issues which let tests fail with some very weird issues. If the issue persists with the next commit, we can try some stuff.
I'll address the comments and rework the getHelp method to produce more useful output (and cover that with more tests).
thanks for the feedback.

@vasia, I can take care of merging both PRs. The overlapping parts don't seem to be too difficult to resolve.

Will update the gelly guide before merging.
Awesome, thanks Till!

Thank you for reacting so quickly to my feedback.
I'm sorry for the delays during the PR review.
any other comments? I'll merge it other wise later on.
Merging this.
I think it's good :+1:

Thanks for the review. I updated the PR in the following way:
- Chill is added as a dependency to `flink-runtime` and will always be in the CP when a job is executed.
- The `KryoSerializer` throws an exception if it cannot obtain a Chill Kryo instance. This ensures all Kryo instances are identically initialized.
- Chill is added as test dependency to `flink-java` to make the serializer tests pass (which have no dependency on `flink-runtime`).
Merging this.

I tested the change against:
- HDP 2.3.2 (Hadoop 2.7.1)
- Cloudera 5.3.0.0 (Hadoop 2.5.0) with Kerberos
- Cloudera 5.4.2.0 (Hadoop 2.6.0)

I think we should add this to the TypeExtractor, otherwise it becomes very clumsy. 

I am using the same logic in my applications and defining the TypeInfo in returns gets awkward after a while and is also harder for the users who are not very familiar with the system (how to use the TypeExtractor.getForObject etc).
I'm assuming everyone is ok with this workaround for now. If not please speak up. I'll merge this in time for 0.10.1.
Otherwise big :+1:  for this, it is very useful, also we should add the java Optional :)

@sachingoel0101 I have a problem testing my changes to the WebUI. It seems that the browser does not load the correct (ie, changed) scripts... Check out the screenshot -- it only shows the unmodified `@cancelJob = (jobid) -> $http.delete "jobs/" + jobid` and the inserted `stop` part is missing (I have almost no experience in web-dev stuff).

I built the hole Flink project with `mvn -DskipTests clean install`; also delete maven repo to get rid of old stuff. I tried to reload (F5 and ctrl+F5 as well as clearing the cache; using a private window did not help either).

Can you help me out? The only change I can see it the new "stop" button -- so `jobs.html` is loaded correctly.

![screenshot - 11182015 - 02 20 59 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8959638/11242126/1959dfc4-8e00-11e5-9840-127174ffabc3.png)

Thanks for digging into this and fixing this.

+1 to merge this

One thing that would be a good sanity check is to see how many overlapping classes the final fat jar shading finds, and make sure there are no others than the Guava/ASM ones that we shade in a fine granular way.

Sure, no problem.

One comment concerning the comment:
The `RequiredParametersException` could list the missing arguments.

At the moment the validation in `applyTo` fails with the first missing parameter. To list all missing arguments would require to change that, but it might be worth it.
What do you think?

Then the missing arguments could be passed to the exception and `getHelp` could get an 'optional' list parameter with missing arguments
The Java Optional comes only in Java 8, so we would need to implement this in a reflective way. But I would like that a lot as well (replacement for nullable fields).
+1 for including it into the type extractor
Looks pretty good, with a few comments inline!
